title: Arrow star Katherine McNamara to star in Stephen King's The Stand
text:
Katherine McNamara will join The Stand (Picture: FilmMagic)

Shadowhunters and Arrow star Katherine McNamara has joined Amber Heard and James Marsden in a small screen retelling of Stephen King’s The Stand.

Once Upon a Time alum Eion Bailey and Legion’s Hamish Linklater are also onboard for the 10-episode event series, based on the 1978 apocalyptic fantasy novel.

‘#THESTAND So excited to finally be able to share this news! Thank you Josh Boone and @cbsallaccess. My @StephenKing fangirl heart is floating today,’ shared Kat.

If you’re unfamiliar, The Stand presents a world where a deadly plague has killed off 99 percent of the population, and was previously adapted into an ABC miniseries in 1994.

Marsden will play Stu Redman, an ordinary, working-class factory man who becomes a leader of the survivors.

Heard has been cast as Nadine Cross, a conflicted woman who is compelled by her allegiance to Randall Flagg, the Dark Man.

TV Line reports that McNamara will play Julie Lawry, ‘a small-town girl with a wild side who has a run-in with Lloyd (Nat Wolff) in Las Vegas’.

Announced during CBS All Access’ summer Television Critics Association presentation, it was also revealed Stephen King will write the final episode of the series – which serves as a ‘new coda’ going beyond events in the book.

Josh Boone is set to direct the series and act as writer and executive producer with Ben Cavell. Roy Lee, Jimmy Miller and Richard P. Rubinstein will also serve as executive producers.

It’s one of many Stephen King adaptations in the pipeline, with IT Chapter Two released in cinemas in September while Doctor Sleep starring Ewan McGregor releases later in 2019.

Kat as Clary Fray in Shadowhunters (Picture: Freeform)

Kat’s role comes after she was confirmed for a new ‘female-centric’ addition to TV’s Arrowverse, with the spin-off focusing on her character Mia Smoak, Oliver Queen and Felicity Smoak’s daughter.

A spin-off has been floated by fans ever since Mia entered the scene in season six and her character’s identity was revealed in season seven, but the news also proves that DC Comics have a smart and exciting stronghold on the small screen when it comes to inclusivity and diversity – and it may be time for Marvel to take a long hard look at themselves.
